entry.title: Project Report
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll sumarize your finding for the class presentation.

The class presentation will use this notebook in slide mode, as I do during lecture time.

You'll need to download the following zip file, unzip it, and run the following notebook install-support.ipynb to install the slide capabilities.

The notebook notebook-slideshow-example.ipynb will give you examples on how to use slides within the iPython notebook.

You should also write this notebook so that you can convert it nicely into a pdf document using the commands

ipython nbconvert NB4_report.pynb --to latex
pdflatex NB4_report.tex

See here for further references on how to do that.

In this notebook, you'll

  • describe your problem as stated in the propectus

  • comment on your data sources, on their format, on the difficulties to get them

  • present the main challenge you encountered

  • present your finding in the form of expresive graphics

Be sure to include an introduction section motivating your visualizations, with a description of the substantive context and why it is interesting.

Cite the source of the data and any other references that you used in carrying out your project.

Team members responsible for this notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • team member 1 name: team member 1 responsabilities
  • team member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities
  • etc.

I advise you to work at least in pairs for each project notebook, as you did for the homework assignments. Of course, all team members may participate to each notebook.

In [1]: 
%load_ext rmagic

Problem¶

In this project, we are building a portfolio on future prediction of stock market in one year time. We are going to compare 3 companies in each of the following three industries: technology, health and retail. Then finding out the best stock in each industry based on the data provided and our analysis. Weâ€™ll put them into a portfolio that only shows stocks with grander prospects. Our analysis will be based on the daily stock price trend of each picked individual stock in a year long, and the peaks and lowest points will be highlighted.

Data¶

We get our data from Yahoo Finance, which has provided daily stock market price information in a large spreadsheet on its website. These data is in a format of API data. In addition, we also acquire the LIBOR rate from the official website of Federal Reserve. They will be used to quantify the stock market trend in each specific field. We use the internet interactive facilities of Python, Bash, and R to get different datasets, highlight the importance, graph the trend and organize them into dataframe portfolio.

Main challenge of this project¶

Since we analysis 3 different area of stock, and each area contains 5 differetnt type of stock, it would be really unefficent to repeat all of the codes for 15 times. Therefore, the biggest challenge for us is to come up with some functions that can make it simple and efficent.

Presentation of our Finding¶

In []: 
from IPython.display import Image
Image(filename='../visualizations/TS_IT.jpg')
Work Cited¶

\(Yahoo\) \(Finance\). 18 April 2014. <http://finance.yahoo.com/>

\(Federal\) \(Reserve\). 25 April 2014. <http://www.federalreserve.gov/datadownload/>

Daroczi, Gergeky, Michael Pchle, Edina Berlinger, Peter Csoka, Daniel Havran, Marton Michaletzky, Zsolt Tulassay, Kata Varadi and Agnes Vidovics-Dancs. \(Introduction\) \(to\) \(R\) \(for\) \(Quantitative\) \(Finance\). Packt Publishing, 2013. Print.

entry.title: Data Analysis
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll perform the actual analysis of the data stored in the directory

./data/cleaned

If the data is not ready yet (e.g. the other members of the team in charge of cleaning the data are not done yet), you may want to simulate cleaned data in the form you want them to be in order to perform the analysis. This may also help you data cleaning team to come up with the rigth data frame. If you choose to do so, store your simulated data into the directory

./data/simulated

Having performed analysis of simulated data may help you with the analysis of the actual data, since you will be able to notice deviations between the real and simulated data, which may be worth explaining and investigating further.

The graphics your going to produce as a result of your analysis should be store in the directory:

./visualization

Team members responsible for this notebook:

Min Variance Function¶

In [105]: 
%%R
# Min Variance Function
minvariance <- function(assets, mu = 0.005) {
        returns  <- log(tail(assets, -1) / head(assets, -1)) # Return
        Q       <- rbind(cov(returns), rep(1, ncol(assets)), colMeans(returns))
        Q       <- cbind(Q, rbind(t(tail(Q,2)), matrix(0, 2, 2)))
        b       <- c(rep(0, ncol(assets)), 1, mu)
        solve(Q,b)
}
In [107]: 
%%R
print(minvariance(IT[,-1]))
print(minvariance(retail[,-1]))
print(minvariance(bank[,-1]))

        Apple        Google        Amazon     Microsoft            HP 
 3.098662e+00  1.406482e+00  2.167257e+00  5.842185e-01  1.026620e+00 
      S.P.500                             
-7.283239e+00  4.275244e-05 -1.500718e+00
In [102]: 
%%R
frontier <- function(assets) {
       returns <- log(tail(assets, -1) / head(assets, -1))
       Q  <- cov(returns)
       n  <- ncol(assets)
       r  <- colMeans(returns)
       Q1 <- rbind(Q, rep(1, n), r)
       Q1 <- cbind(Q1, rbind(t(tail(Q1, 2)), matrix(0, 2, 2)))
       rbase <- seq(min(r), max(r), length = 100)
       s  <- sapply(rbase, function(x) {
           y <- head(solve(Q1, c(rep(0, n), 1, x)), n)
           y %*% Q %*% y 
       })
       plot(s, rbase, xlab = 'Returns', ylab = 'Variance', main = 'Profolio Frontier')
   }
In [108]: 
%%R
frontier(IT[,-1])
frontier(retail[,-1])
frontier(bank[,-1])

entry.title: Data Cleaning
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll

  • load the raw data into R or Pandas dataframe from the ./data/raw directory using the functions and classes (written during the data gathering phase) in the ./script directory

  • perform visual exploration on your data variables to detect anomalies, errors, outliers, interesting features etc.

  • clean categorical and quantitative variables (by removing observations and variables with too many missing values, by consolidating categorical variables, by selecting an appropriate subset of variables and observations for later analysis, etc.)

  • save the cleaned data into csv files in the ./data/cleaned directory

  • save interesting graphics you obtained during visual exploration into the ./visualiation directory

Team members responsible for this notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • team member 1 Hui, Man Kin (Ken): Transform the Data to Time Series, and Gathering the Data by Category
  • team member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities
  • etc.

I advise you to work at least in pairs for each project notebook, as you did for the homework assignments. Of course, all team members may participate to each notebook.

Cleaning LIBOR Data¶

Cleaning¶

In [6]: 
%%R
# Loading Libor CSV
libor = read.csv("../data/raw/libor.csv", skip=5, stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
colnames(libor) = c("Time", "1 Month Rate")

# Subset Libor
libor = libor[which(libor$Time == "2008-03-31"):which(libor$Time == "2014-04-30"),]

# Removing Missing Data
remove_list = which(libor$"1 Month Rate" == "ND")*-1
libor = libor[remove_list,]

# Saving to CSV
write.csv(file='../data/cleaned/libor.csv', x=libor, row.names=FALSE)

Making Daily Data¶

In [9]: 
# Loading Data to Panda
for stock in stocks_d:
    fname = '../data/raw/'+stock['symbol']+'.csv' # Path
    stock['pd'] = pd.read_csv(fname, index_col='Date') # Loading Data
    stock['pd']['Adj Close'].to_csv('../data/cleaned/d'+stock['symbol']+'.csv', index_label='Date', header='Adj Close') # Saving Daily Data to CSV

    print('Daily Data - '+stock['name']) # Displaying Daily Data
    dfname = '../data/cleaned/d'+stock['symbol']+'.csv' # Path for Daily Data
    !head $dfname
    print('')

In [11]: 
%%R
library(zoo) # Loading "zoo" Library
library(xts) # Loading "xts" Library

# Reading Daily Data
stocks$read.code = sapply(stocks$symbol, function(x) paste0("read.zoo('../data/cleaned/d",x, ".csv', header=TRUE, sep=',', format = '%Y-%m-%d')"))

# Calculating Weekly Average through xts Library
myweek = sapply(stocks$read.code, function(x) apply.weekly(eval(parse(text = x)),mean))

# Making List of DataFrame
a = list()
for (i in 1:ncol(myweek)){
    a[[i]] = data.frame("Week" = rownames(myweek), "Adj Close" = myweek[,i])}

# Saving DataFrame to CSV
for (stock in stocks$symbol){
    fname = paste0("write.csv(file='../data/cleaned/w",stock,".csv', x=",a, ",row.names=FALSE)")
    eval(parse(text=fname))}

%%R
# Function
adjclosecombine = function(a, b, c, d, e, f){
    data.frame(a$Date, a$"Adj.Close", b$"Adj.Close", c$"Adj.Close", d$"Adj.Close", e$"Adj.Close", f$"Adj.Close")
}

%%R
# Making IT Stock Data
IT = adjclosecombine(readstocks[[1]], readstocks[[2]], readstocks[[3]], readstocks[[4]], readstocks[[5]], readstocks[[6]])
colnames(IT) = c("Date", "Apple", "Google", "Amazon", "Microsoft", "HP", "S&P 500")

entry.title: Data Gathering
entry.summary:
In this notebook, you'll

  • create the directory structure for your project
  • download the raw data for your project
  • write functions and classes to transform raw data (e.g in XML, jason, etc.) into data frames
  • explain what your are doing

Team Members Responsible for This Notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • Team Member 1 Hui, Man Kin (Ken): Write Code for Downloading Data from API
  • Team Member 2 name: team member 2 responsabilities
  • etc.

I advise you to work at least in pairs for each project notebook, as you did for the homework assignments. Of course, all team members may participate to each notebook.

Using R Magic¶

In [4]: 
# Loading R Magic
%load_ext rmagic

The rmagic extension is already loaded. To reload it, use:
  %reload_ext rmagic

Import Datetime & Pandas¶

In [5]: 
# Import Datetime & Pandas
import datetime
import pandas as pd
import pandas.io.data
from pandas import Series, DataFrame

Creating Directory¶

In the step below, we created the directory structure for our project.

In [6]: 
%%bash
# Creating directory - script, data (with raw, cleaned, simulated), and visualizations
mkdir ../script ../data ../data/raw ../data/cleaned ../data/simulated ../visualizations
ls -r

Downloading Data¶

Function for Downloading Stock Data from Yahoo Finance API¶

In [7]: 
# Function for Downloading Raw Data from Yahoo API
def download(a):
    return(pd.io.data.get_data_yahoo(a,
                                     start = datetime.datetime(2008, 3, 31),
                                     end = datetime.datetime(2014, 3, 31)))

Downloading and Displaying Raw Data¶

Yahoo Finance Data¶

Source: http://finance.yahoo.com/

In [11]: 
# Downloading Raw Data
# Mapping Dictionary
stocks = [{'name': 'Apple', 'symbol': 'aapl'},
          {'name': 'Google', 'symbol': 'googl'},
          {'name': 'Amazon', 'symbol': 'amzn'},
          {'name': 'Microsoft', 'symbol': 'msft'},
          {'name': 'HP', 'symbol': 'hp'},
          {'name': 'SP500', 'symbol': '^GSPC'},
          {'name': 'Target', 'symbol': 'tgt'},
          {'name': 'Costco', 'symbol': 'cost'},
          {'name': 'Walmart', 'symbol': 'wmt'},
          {'name': 'Walgreen', 'symbol': 'wag'},
          {'name': 'Safeway', 'symbol': 'swy'},
          {'name': 'Citibank', 'symbol': 'ctbk'},
          {'name': 'Wells Fargo', 'symbol': 'wfc'},
          {'name': 'Bank of America', 'symbol': 'bac'},
          {'name': 'JP Morgan', 'symbol': 'jpm'},
          {'name': 'Bank of Ozarks', 'symbol': 'ozrk'}]

for stock in stocks:
    stock['pd'] = download(stock['symbol'].upper()) # Downloading Data
    fname = '../data/raw/'+stock['symbol']+'.csv' # Path
    stock['pd'].to_csv(fname) # Saving Raw Data to CSV
    print('Raw Data - '+stock['name']) # Displaying Data
    !head $fname
    print('')
